image.altText: a close-up of an aboriginal man in army uniform looking at camera

props.synopsis: In an era of spy satellites and nuclear submarines, Australia's vast northern borders are still being defended by squadrons of soldiers using techniques that are thousands of years old.

title.children: From a secret location in the Top End, these soldiers use ancient techniques to defend Australia

image.altText: a composite image one showing a flooded are with trees an looking green the other a sunset after a hot day

props.synopsis: Next week to bring a repeat of wild weather across many parts of Australia, after a surprisingly wet November.

title.children: East Coast Low makes way for severe thunderstorms, a December scorcher, and Coral Sea cyclone

image.altText: A woman with a trolley stands in a stocked supermarket aisle.

props.synopsis: The product feels lighter, or it's smaller, and you can't quite put your finger on the changeâ€¦ but there is a change. Shrinkflation is becoming more widespread, but can anything be done about it, asks David Taylor.

title.children: 'Shrinkflation' is becoming more widespread, but there's one thing shoppers can do to avoid it

image.altText: A woman wearing a hijab limps while holding a man's hand who is wearing a mask.

props.synopsis: Gaza's Hamas-run healthy ministry says 109 Palestinians have been killed since the temporary truce expired on Friday.

title.children: Gaza's Hamas-run health ministry says more than 100 Palestinians killed as IDF strikes 'terror targets'

image.altText: A person wearing a keffiyeh holds their fingers up in a peace sign, a Palestinian flag is in the background.

props.synopsis: What happened in the aftermath of the Sydney Theatre Company performance is a reflection of how the latest conflict in the Middle East has erupted into bitter and dangerous reductionism in political debates in Australia, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Three young actors took to the stage in keffiyehs. A bitter and dangerous debate was unleashed

image.altText: A woman with black hair leans in to a man wearing a green jumper.

props.synopsis: The Kremlin is yet to comment on the alleged poisoning attempt on the wife of Ukraine's chief spy, but if Russian agents are involved, it suggests that Soviet era tactic remains alive and well in the new age of war.

title.children: Why female Putin critics from Russia and Ukraine might be the target of a new wave of poisonings

image.altText: A funeral that shows a tribute and people standing with their head downs

props.synopsis: The son of South Australia's police commissioner has been remembered as a "force of nature" in a touching memorial service, as more than $45,000 is raised for a youth foundation in his honour.

title.children: 'We will love you forever, Charlie boy': SA police commissioner's son farewelled at public twilight service

image.altText: Students in a classroom with male teacher in background.

props.synopsis: Australia's teachers are not equipped to deal with rising levels of disruption in classrooms, a Senate inquiry has found, while calling for students to be taught how to behave.

title.children: Teachers need better training to deal with increasingly disruptive school students, inquiry says

image.altText: A close up headshot of a police officer

props.synopsis: An early report into a shooting that killed a police officer in regional South Australia has found the two surviving officers who were involved performed their duties with "courage and bravery".

title.children: SA Police says surviving officers acted with 'bravery', as inquiry into deadly shooting continues

image.altText: Bare branches covering a large beige building in the background

props.synopsis: The 16-year-old South Australian boy has been sentenced as an adult to three years in prison, but is now eligible to apply for parole after his time served in youth detention was taken into account.

title.children: Schoolboy sentenced over terrorism offences including possessing 'graphic and disturbing videos'

image.altText: Close-up of woman's face and hands putting on a mask during the coronavirus pandemic in Australia.

props.synopsis: We've been hearing about a rise in cases over the past month, butÂ the eighth wave appears to have peaked in some jurisdictions. Let's get you up to speed.

title.children: Has Australia's eighth COVID-19 wave peaked? Here's the latest from each state and territory

image.altText: A man playing the piano and singing onstage

props.synopsis: Adelaide 36ers star Isaac Humphries made international headlines last year when he announced publicly that he is gay, becoming the first NBL player to do so. Now he's preparing to reveal another side of himself â€“ his singing talents â€“ on stage at the biggest arts festival in the southern hemisphere.

title.children: 'I've hidden a lot of my life for so long': Basketball star to reveal new side of himself on major festival stage

image.altText: A close up of Jim speaking in a suit and orange tie outside a building during the day.

props.synopsis: As Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers completes the finishing touches on his mid-year economic outlook, heâ€™s been urged by his state and territory counterparts to make the GST 'no-worse-off guarantee' a permanent arrangement.

title.children: Jim Chalmers urged by states and territories to make GST arrangements permanent

image.altText: A woman with glasses looking serious in front of a yellow wall

props.synopsis: Almost two dozen South Australian teenagers in state care who are at risk of sexual exploitation and abuse have been unable to get the help they need from a specialist public health service that has reached capacity, according to the state's child protection watchdog

title.children: At-risk South Australian children in care miss out on specialist support, child protection watchdog warns

image.altText: A four-wheel drive goes through dunes at Stockton beach - two other four-wheel drives are behind the car.

props.synopsis: Wildlife groups in SA have found some unlikely allies in their lobbying for better protection of bird habitat, with 4WD clubs supporting the need for seasonal restrictions.

title.children: South Australia 'behind other states' when it comes to beach protection

image.altText: Elaine Crombie with her fist raised in the air in front of midden shells on mound of dirt in The 7 Stages of Grieivng

props.synopsis: The Sydney Theatre Company is again under fire after a video shows cast members of The Visitors calling for a Gaza ceasefire, but actor Elaine Crombie says the company knew about it.

title.children: Sydney Theatre Company knew beforehand of cast's pro-Palestinian statement after show, actor says

image.altText: Paul Singer, founder of Elliott Management

props.synopsis: Elliott Management is little-known outside the world of high finance, but throughout its legendary history it's made many enemies, including the Argentine navy. It's now eyeing a stoush with an Australian state over energy.

title.children: Why one of the most feared investors in the world holds the key to an Australian energy crisis

image.altText: A group of people holding umbrellas

props.synopsis: A magistrate says the deaths of five teenagers in a crash in south-west Sydney last year were "completely avoidable" after jailing driver Tyrell Edwards for 12 years.

title.children: Gasps in court as Buxton P-plate driver jailed for 12 years over crash that killed five teenagers

image.altText: Pallbearers carry Cleveland Dodd's casket at the teenager's funeral.

props.synopsis: After a morning of confusion and anguish, Cleveland Dodd's funeral has begun, with WA authorities reversing an eleventh-hour decision to block his incarcerated father from attending.

title.children: Cleveland Dodd's funeral begins as father arrives back in town, after ban reversed

image.altText: Brittany Higgins outside court with an inset image of her going through Parliament House security.

props.synopsis: Brittany Higgins tells the Federal Court she tried to "reclaim" the dress she alleges she was sexually assaulted in by wearing it at a Liberal Party function in the months afterwards.

title.children: Brittany Higgins re-wore dress she was allegedly raped in to 'reclaim' it, court hears

image.altText: A man wearing a patterned shirt with his arm around a woman wearing a black top and bright pink scarf.

props.synopsis: State leaders are calling for the federal government to amend Commonwealth laws and allow telehealth consultations for patients seeking access to voluntary assisted dying services, in the wake of a Federal Court ruling.

title.children: In John's final weeks of life, travelling for voluntary assisted dying appointments was 'a very big ask'

image.altText: Sunset over a bend in the majestic Murray River at Murtho, with red tall cliffs

props.synopsis: First Nations water groups have welcomed changes to the Murray-Darling Basin Plan which will formally acknowledge their connection to water and aim to increase Indigenous ownership.Â Â

title.children: Murray-Darling Basin Plan changes recognise a First Nations connection to water in 'small step forward'

image.altText: A close up photo of the front of a Tesla Cybertruck in a showroom, with some people standing behind it

props.synopsis: Experts say Elon Musk's electric car company is not living up to some of its promises as it delivers its first all-new model in nearly four years.

title.children: Tesla begins deliveries of long-delayed Cybertruck, with higher prices and lower range than first announced

props.synopsis: An AI-based analysis of 20 years of logging by VicForests, shared exclusively with the ABC, shows for the first time the potential scale of failed regeneration in Victoria's state forests.

title.children: 'It's basically dead': The legacy of decades of logging

image.altText: The outside of the County Court of Victoria building.

props.synopsis: In 1984, Robert Barry chased down a 24-year-old woman and raped her in a "degrading" attack. Nearly four decades on, he has been sentenced in a Victorian court.

title.children: Forty-year-old rape case solved through 'Cold Case Freezer Project'

image.altText: A map showing congested areas in and around the Rozelle Interchange

props.synopsis: The much-discussed Rozelle Interface has proved to have teething problems after opening on Sunday. But experts say it isn't user error.

title.children: Sydney's multi-billion-dollar roadway with choke points designers didn't see coming

image.altText: A graphic showing a confused person looking at different plastics.

props.synopsis: Does a product wrapped in earthy beige make you feel it must be environmentally responsible?Â New research shows how easy it is for marketers to imply their products are "sustainable" without necessarily backing it up.

title.children: These are the tricks advertisers use to fake sustainable products

image.altText: Shoebridge gestures with a hand as he speaks inside the mural hall.

props.synopsis: Amid the continuing conflict in Gaza, Greens spokesman for Defence and Veterans' Affairs David Shoebridge says the government is selling "weapons, after weapons, after weapons" to Israel. RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked David Shoebridge on Australia selling weapons to Israel. Here's what we found

image.altText: Peter Dutton smile

props.synopsis: If the government's position doesn't improve substantially, people will take a more serious look at Peter DuttonÂ â€” the hard man from Queensland â€” and speculate about what sort of prime minister he'd make, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: What would happen if Dutton managed to win the election? What kind of prime minister would he make?

image.altText: A house with a red roof underwater

props.synopsis: Less than $900,000 out of $12m has been handed out to victims of the Fitzroy River flood disaster in January. Just 24 people have received money.

title.children: Millions of dollars in Kimberley flood donations still locked up, 11 months on from the disaster

image.altText: Hands move over a scrabble board covered in tiles

props.synopsis: The board game almost hit the shelves 75 years ago without a board and under a very different moniker: Criss-Crosswords.Â

title.children: The longest Scrabble word gets you 1,778 points â€” Australian players say the game gives them much more important things
